Between 2000-2009, more than 2.2 billion people were affected by 4,484 natural disasters. Vulnerability to hazards is increasing as a result of demographic, political and environmental changes. Demand for humanitarian assistance is likely to rise while economic constraints are also increasing. In this context it is important to ensure that the most effective and cost efficient approaches are being used to reduce risk and save lives when disasters strike. This programme will develop and test innovative approaches to humanitarian practice; provide evidence of the cost effectiveness of investments in disaster risk reduction; provide new evidence on the scaling up of cash-based approaches; support better evidence on insurance as a risk management tool; and create new evidence on the best intervention to improve health and nutrition in emergencies, regions -> , countries -> , id -> GB-1-203705, status -> Implementation, formattedBudget -> £25,216,624, budget -> 25216624, title -> Humanitarian Innovation and Evidence Programme: greater use of evidence and innovation in humanitarian responses, organizations -> Department for International Development#INTERNATIONAL NGO#UNITED KINGDOM)Map(sectors -> Multisector, subActivities -> GB-1-202545-101, description -> To provide strategic funding to Restless Development in support of agreed outcomes  in their PPA Performance Framework., regions -> , countries -> , id -> GB-1-202545, status -> Implementation, formattedBudget -> £8,266,317, budget -> 8266317, title -> Restless Development Programme Partnership Arrangement, organizations -> Department for International Development#Donor country-based NGO#UNITED KINGDOM)Map(sectors -> Multisector, subActivities -> GB-1-203805-101, description -> This research will identify and analyse a preliminary set of practical examples of donor experience in risk taking and risk management in fragile and conflict-affected states. and (b) improved understanding and use of national research capacity in South Asia., regions -> Asia, regional, countries -> Pakistan, id -> GB-1-203200, status -> Implementation, formattedBudget -> GB-1-203157-101, description -> This initiative, which DFID is co-funding with the Shell Foundation, will support research into reducing the cost and increasing the application of mobile-to-mobile  technology that  both reduce the costs and increase the availability of products and services (for example solar lanterns and other household appliances) to poor people. It will do this by testing ways of enabling poor people to pay for such appliances in small increments as they use them, thereby both reducing the initial purchase costs which are often prohibitive for the poor, and by demonstrating the viability of alternative, lower cost business/retail models to the enterprise sector.  The research will also potentially help make available to poor people cleaner, more effective/efficient technologies at an affordable price. Initial products to be tested will be focused on energy access technologies (such as solar home systems), but results will be relevant for other products in other sectors., regions -> , countries -> is the first international document which clearly sets out the implications of existing international law in relation to the human rights of people living in extreme poverty. The aim of the revised version of the draft Guiding Principles is to facilitate and inform the meaningful application of international human rights standards by practitioners and those working for the elimination of extreme poverty. The Draft Guiding Principles will interpret existing standards and be a practical tool, offering operational guidance to States and other actors.
